In an unusual legal move, the Obama administration has taken the legal side of the Palestinian Authority and Palestine Liberation Organization in a federal court case that American terrorism victims' families had already won.Lawyers for the Justice and State Departments are arguing that the PA and PLO should not have to post a bond showing they can pay the massive damages during their appeal in U.S. federal court.One of the families' attorneys argued otherwise. "The State Department should stand on the side of the American terror

victims and not on the side of the Palestinian suicide bombers," said Nitsana Darshan-Leitner of the Israel Law Center.The jury's judgment against the Palestinian groups came in a case, Sokolow v. PLO, before Manhattan U.S. District Judge George Daniels in February and could involve penalties of more than $650 million, triple the amount of damages awarded by the jury under U.S. law, plus interest.The money would go to victims in seven deadly terrorist attacks in Israel between 2001 and 2004, including 11 American families. Hundreds were injured and 33 killed in the attacks.For defendants to appeal the immense judgment, the judge can require them to post a bond of a substantial portion of the damages in case they lose again. Judge Daniels had said he was likely to order that as “some meaningful demonstration that the defendant is ready and willing to pay the judgment.”However, last week in a strange move lawyers for the
American administration, which had not been a party to the lawsuit, sought to
save the Palestinians from having to post bond during their legal

appeal. That leaves the financial awards to American families uncovered. So, whose side is this White House on?The administration's affidavit, including a statement by Deputy Secretary of State Anthony Blinken, claimed the Palestinians' ability to govern would be "severely compromised" by such a substantial bond. Although apparently no one on the Palestinian side considered the consequences on the attacks' victims or its own financial culpability for sponsoring such acts.The U.S. statement added: "The continued viability of the PA is essential to key U.S. security and diplomatic interests, including advancing peace between Israel and the Palestinians, supporting the security of U.S. allies such as Israel, Jordan and Egypt, combating extremism and terrorism, and promoting good governance."Officials tried to claim they were not taking sides by helping the Palestinians avoid financial responsibility for the attacks in Israel. "This filing is a statement of the interests of the United States and not on behalf of any party,” a State Department spokesman said, although the financial impact would be to the benefit of the guilty defendants.That claim of not taking sides was hotly disputed by the families' attorneys.One of them, Darshan Leitner, heads Shurat HaDin-Israel Law Center, a nonprofit based in Tel Aviv. It has become known internationally as a kind of legal pitbull going after the finances and financiers of terrorism globally."Bankrupting terror one lawsuit at a time," is its motto. A major goal of the Israel Law Center is economically destroying Middle Eastern terror groups by tracking their assets and bank accounts and legally obstructing and restraining their funds. To date, the center has won terrorism judgments in excess of $2 billion and collected more than $200 million for victims.By taking sides to help the PLO avoid bond, Darshan-Leitner added:"The State Department ignores the fact that Palestinians continue to pay monthly payments to imprisoned terrorists and to the families of the suicide bombers, who devastated the lives of the victims in this case. If the Palestinians have the funds to continue making these payments, they certainly have the funds to post a bond."Now, it's up to the judge. Next court date is Aug. 24.RELATED:ISIS uses mustard gas on the Kurds: Is this an Obama red line?Forget terror, Obama tells military global warming is bigger threatWhite House declares war with ISIS a 'success,' but for whose side?

War On Terror: Besides Israel, no nation has helped the U.S. fight Islamist terror more than the world's largest people without a country, the Kurds. America should stop taking them for granted.Despite its NATO membership, and its misleading image as supposedly the most Western of Muslim nations, Turkey is quite anti-American, more so than many Mideast Islamic states.Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has been little help against the Islamic State. As mayor of Istanbul in 1997, celebrating the city's Ottoman conquest, he is on record as saying: "The image of the Jews is no different from that of the Nazis."Turkey openly supports the al-Qaida-allied Syrian groups Jabhat al Nusra and Ahrar ash Sham. And Erdogan was just in Beijing, forging links with our global adversary China, which over many years helped Iran build its nuclear program.Today, Erdogan's armed forces play a game of simultaneously combating Islamic State and Kurdish separatists. The unexpected deal allowing the U.S. to use the strategically well-located Incirlik Air Base — from where it can utilize 30 fighter jets and 300 troops against Islamic State locations in northern Syria — must be viewed in that context of Turkey's dubious long-term objectives.After Turkish intelligence was apparently helping Islamic State forces move to and fro across Turkey's Syrian border, now all of a sudden the Turks are getting serious about airstrikes against the Islamic State — as they hit Kurdish forces hard too.Too great a Kurdish victory over the Islamic State in the coming weeks would spell a de-facto Kurdish state on Turkey's southern border, which Erdogan has made clear he won't tolerate.So President Obama is actually coordinating with Turkey, when it is the Kurds who have been our most effective allies against the Islamic State — the unspeakably savage Islamic State, of course, being an entity brought into being by Obama's policies of abandoning Iraq.Modestly armed, this valiant people, fighting alongside regional Arab and Christian forces, defeated the Islamic State barbarians again and again, in Kobani, Tel Abyad, and Hassakeh, to name just a few victory sites. And unlike ethnic-cleansing Shiite militants, they didn't leave a trail of beheaded innocents in their wake.Since Iraq's and Syria's borders are in flux thanks to the Islamic State, we should think seriously about backing the Kurds — who have so loyally backed us — in their long-delayed and much-deserved national aspirations.

NantKwest (NK) raised $207 million in an upsized IPO Monday evening, pricing 8.3 million shares at 25 and boosting the hot biotech sector.It had planned to raise $151 million by offering 7 million shares at a price range of 20 to 23.NantKwest is one of eight IPOs planned for the week of July 27 that look to raise about $2 billion.NantKwest is developing therapies for the treatment of cancer, in the hot field of immunotherapy that includes recent biotech IPOs such as Juno Therapeutics (JUNO).The stock was said to be in high demand among institutional buyers, according to research firm IPO boutique. It is the 51st initial public offering in the health care field this year.That's more than triple the next most active sectors, technology and finance, with 15 IPOs each. Health care also had the most IPOs last year, at 102. On analyst referred to this as the golden age of biotechnology.Another biotech IPO this week is vTv Therapeutics (VTVT), which is developing treatments for Alzheimer's disease and type 2 diabetes. It plans to raise $125 million by offering 7.8 million shares at 15 to 17. It will list under the ticker VTVT on the Nasdaq, trading Thursday.It follows the June 11 IPO of Axovant Sciences (AXON), also a developer of therapies for Alzheimer's, which raised $315 million on its June 11 IPO and priced at 15. Axovant closed Monday at 15.58.The largest IPO of the week is TerraForm Global (GLBL), a yieldco formed by SunEdison (SUNE), which plans to raise $1.13 billion. It's offering 56.6 million shares at 19 to 21. TerraForm Global will own and operate SunEdison power generation assets in emerging markets. It is set to list on the Nasdaq under the ticker GLBL, trading Friday.Also this week is Poseidon Containers Holdings (PCON), which operates a fleet of fuel-efficient container ships. It plans to raise $231 million by offering 15.4 million shares at 14 to 16. Poseidon will list on the NYSE under the ticker PCON, trading Thursday.NEP Group (NEPG) looks to raise $208 million, offering 13 million shares at 15 to 17. The company is a provider of outsourced broadcast services, including premium sports, entertainment and other live event production markets. NEP will list on the NYSE under the ticker NEPG, trading Friday.One real-estate investment trust is on the IPO list. RiverBanc Multifamily Investors (RMI), which invests in apartment communities, plans to raise $74 million by offering 3.8 million shares at 19 to 20. RiverBanc will list on the Nasdaq under the ticker RMI, trading Friday.Another IPO in the health care field this week is Intec Pharma (NTEC), listed on the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange under the symbol INTP. The Israel-based company plans to raise $38 million by offering 4.5 million shares at its current price of about 8.36. Intec will list on the Nasdaq under the ticker NTEC. A trading day has not been listed.Snack food company Amplify Snack Brands (BETR) plans to raise $225 million, offering 15 million shares at 14 to 16. Amplify will list on the NYSE under the ticker BETR, trading Wednesday.
Stocks flew into Friday's session in tightly mixed formation, with earnings news squarely at the center of early action.
The Nasdaq climbed 0.5%, passing its June 24 peak to notch a new high. The S&P 500 dipped 0.2%, the Dow Jones industrial average backed off 0.5%.

Volume was higher, up 6% on the Nasdaq while surging 51% on the NYSE. The Nasdaq ran hot, with Google (GOOGL), Facebook (FB), Priceline.com (PCLN) and Tesla Motors (TSLA) powering to the front of the Nasdaq 100. Dow stocks were cooler, with only a handful of issues gaining ground, and none of those as much as a half-percent.

Positive economic news appeared to have little to no impact on the stock market today. Consumer price data showed inflation action in check, increasing in line with expectations during June. Big homebuilders Toll Bros. (TOL), Pulte (PHM), Lennar (LEN) and D.R. Horton (DHI) slipped, despite a surge in July housing starts and building permits.

Consumers' views ebbed a bit in July, with the University of Michigan's initial estimate on its Consumer Sentiment Index easing to 93.3. That was a wide step down from June's 96.1 tally, undercutting expectations for 96.
A big rollout of second-quarter earnings reports imposed a mixed effect on early trade.
General Electric (GE) and Schlumberger (SLB) rose a fraction each. Sweden-based telecom giant Ericsson (ERIC) climbed nearly 4%. Mattel (MAT) and Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) each shed more than 2%.

Google surged 14% out of the gate, as mobile search products led a broad advance in company revenue. Second-quarter results showed earnings and revenue topping analyst consensus views. Cost increases slowed. So did paid ad clicks, rising 18%, vs. a 25% increase during the same period last year. Watch time at Google's YouTube unit swelled 60% during the quarter, its fastest growth in two years. The gain left shares at a new high and 17% above a 584.80 buy point in a flat base.
A number of China-based stocks were hammering out strong early moves after a positive week for recently hard-hit markets in China. Baidu (BIDU) swept up more than 3%. Noah (NOAH) rose 2%.

Railroad Kansas City Southern (KSU) pared some early gains, but remained up 5% after reporting mixed Q2 results. Earnings narrowly topped forecasts, but revenue fell 10% — more than expected. S&P Capital IQ trimmed the stock's price target to 120, from 143, but kept its buy rating. The move put Kansas City back above its 10-week moving average, but the stock has been unwinding since November.

Two in every five IBD 50 stocks gained at the open. Facebook topped the list, jumping 3% to a new high. The stock is a bit shy of 9% past a flat-base buy point of 86.17. Iran Deal: The president claims that if Tehran cheats, "sanctions that have helped to cripple the Iranian economy will snap back into place." But he won't want them to, because then the deal would be dead.Should Iran violate any aspect of this deal," the White House tells us, "the UN, U.S. and EU can snap the sanctions that have crippled Iran's economy back into place."But "can" doesn't mean "will.""Snap back" is a cool term. It's what adjustable baseball caps worn backwards have long been called in hip-hop black urban culture.The way the snapback mechanism works, if the U.S. or one of the other P5+1 believes that Iran is cheating, it can convene a United Nations Security Council vote on sanctions in which the U.S. or another permanent Security Council member could veto continued sanctions relief, thus reinstating sanctions on Iran in 30 days.An unnamed U.S. official boasted that the U.S., not Russia or China, now has the veto: "We flipped the presumption so the veto works to our advantage."But the process also requires going through an international "joint commission," then an international "advisory board," which would likely take more than two months. Moreover, within the agreement is a key passage: "Iran has stated that if sanctions are reinstated in whole or in part, Iran will treat that as grounds to cease performing its commitments" under the pact.In other words, if Iran cheats and we do anything about it, the deal is dead. Is Barack Obama going to do that? Not on your legacy (or, rather, his). And the next president, even a Republican, might have reasons not to do it either.As Pascal-Emmanuel Gobry, an Ethics and Public Policy Center fellow, writes in TheWeek.com: "In the real world, once sanctions are scrapped, political pressure to keep the sanctions gone, particularly from elites in places that do business with Iran — like Russia, China, Germany and France — will be enormous."What's more, a paper last month from the Foundation For Defense of Democracies warned, "In the later years of the agreement, international companies may have invested tens of billions of dollars back into Iran and will likely be less willing to forgo their business interests because of Iranian nuclear violations."So the soon-to-come sanctions relief under the pact will actually blunt the pain of re-imposed sanctions.Obama conceded Wednesday that Iran is a terrorist menace "that has proclaimed that Israel shouldn't exist, that has denied the Holocaust, that has financed Hezbollah, and as a consequence there are missiles that are pointed towards Tel Aviv." But his deal should be accepted because "all those threats are compounded if Iran gets a nuclear weapon."Unfortunately, even in the unlikely event that sanctions do "snap back," his deal's initial sanctions relief compounds those threats — without Iran getting a nuke. And then, in the end, through cheating on the deal, an economically stronger Tehran, less fearful of re-imposed sanctions, will likely end up with nuclear weapons anyway.

Stocks faltered in early trade Thursday despite a healthy improvement in the Midwest manufacturing picture.

The Nasdaq slumped 1%, the S&P 500 stalled 0.6%, and the Dow Jones industrial average backed down 0.7%. Volume rose 14% on the Nasdaq and was 6% higher on the NYSE, compared to trade at the same time Wednesday.

The stock market today received a mixed send-off from the Labor and Commerce departments, which reported a sharp drop in weekly unemployment claims but no gain in workers' incomes in March and a less-than-estimated gain in consumer spending.

Better news came from Kingsbury International and the Institute for Supply Management, which reported that its Chicago Purchasing Managers Index jumped to 52.3 in March. The number was the highest since January and above expectations for a gain to 50. New orders led the surge, the ISM noted, and businesses were unconcerned about a possible pending change in Federal Reserve policy.
Leading stocks were in motion — both good and bad — in early trade.

Drug wholesaler AmerisourceBergen (ABC) leapt 6% after a sold fiscal second quarter sales and earnings beat. The Chesterbrook, Pa. company reported a 37% jump in earnings on a 15% revenue gain. Analysts had expected a 12% earnings gain. Management hoisted its full-year earnings guidance to well above consensus views. The gap-up gain sent shares to a new high, extended well beyond a flat-base breakout in January.

Harman International Industries (HAR) crumbled 13% at the open. The maker of high-end audio and entertainment gear reported disappointing fiscal third quarter results, with both earnings and revenue stopping well short of consensus expectations. The loss marked a clear sell signal for Harman, sending shares through their 10-week moving average in heavy trade.

CommScope Holding (COMM) jumped 7% higher after Q1 earnings slipped less than expected. Revenue fell more than projected, and management trimmed its Q2 guidance to below analyst estimates. The company reasserted full-year earnings guidance range in line with projections. The company also reported that federal regulators had terminated U.S. antitrust proceedings with regard to the company's proposed acquisition of TE Connectivity 's (TEL) Telecom, Enterprise and Wireless businesses. CommScope has been in a mild consolidation since early March.

Network services provider Equinix (EQIX) popped 4% in early action. The Redwood City, Calif., company's first-quarter earnings and revenue stormed past analyst forecasts. Management boosted its Q2 revenue guidance and offered full-year guidance roughly in line with expectations. ChipmakerSkyworks Solutions (SWKS) is poised to significantly expand its global presence as well as its profit margins over the next two years, according to an analyst report released late Monday.As Chinese telecom carriers transition from 2G phones to 3G smartphones and 4G LTE wireless broadband services for customers, Skyworks is likely to have a strong presence in what will be a big market."We anticipate a growing global mix of LTE smartphones and Skyworks' share gains with leading Chinese OEMs should drive 15% plus sales growth into the smartphone market over the next two years," said Canaccord Genuity analyst Michael Walkley in a research report. "The potential dollar content available for Skyworks increases from roughly 30 cents to 50 cents in a 2G phone to $2 to $3 in a lower-end 3G smartphone to $4 to $6 for a midtier LTE smartphone and to $10-plus for high-end global LTE smartphones," he said.Walkley increased his target price on Skyworks stock to 62 from 55, and reiterated a buy rating.Skyworks stock was flat, near 52, in midday trading in the stock market today, but shares are up more than 80% this year for a company that has been in the IBD 50 list of top-performing stocks for weeks, as well as an IBD Leaderboard stock."Given Skyworks' broad RFIC (radio frequency integrated circuit) portfolio and customer base, we believe Skyworks' diverse analog portfolio is enabling content share gains in its smartphone customer base," Walkley said. "Further, we anticipate strong ongoing sales to Wi-Fi 802.11ac, wireless infrastructure, and the IoT (Internet of Things) markets should contribute to strong sales and improving margins."The report was released after meetings with Don Palette, Skyworks' chief financial officer, at a Canaccord investor conference last week.The Woburn, Mass.-based company has a diverse portfolio of analog chips used in cars, broadband gear, cellular infrastructure, energy management, GPS devices, smartphones and tablets.Skyworks chips are used in the Apple (AAPL) iPhone and Samsung Galaxy F4 and F5, but recently its chip growth is being driven in part by fitness wearables, such as Philips ' (PHG) wearable technologies and wellness applications, and by home automation, JMP Securities analyst Alex Gauna told IBD."They're in a lot of new automobile applications," Gauna said. "The automobile is so sensor-intensive now, with a lot of RF (radio frequency) and analog content that Skyworks can provide."New product launches and an aggressive push into new markets have helped drive recent revenue growth. For its fiscal Q3 ended June 30, Skyworks posted year-over-year revenue growth of 35%, its biggest growth in more than three years."While we understand investor concerns regarding slowing smartphone/handset unit sales growth, we believe investors do not fully appreciate Skyworks' diverse content opportunities, increasing mix of higher-margin integrated mobile solutions vs. stand-alone power amplifiers, and improving competitive position," Walkley said.Skyworks products, for instance, will help enable navigation-assist capabilities in some of next year's Volkswagen (VLKAY) models and will go into Ericsson's (ERIC) 4G LTE mobile broadband base stations. Skyworks chips are going into enhanced video-streaming applications for TV set-top boxes, Blu-ray/ DVD players and LED/4K television.Skyworks also sees promising opportunities in medical devices, gaming platforms and industrial markets.RELATED:Worldwide smartphone market grows in Q2.

The Pentagon plans to open an office in Silicon Valley as it looks to beef up its cybersecurity and build more advanced weapon systems.

The news is set to be announced at Secretary of Defense Ashton Carter's speech at Stanford University on Thursday for an event called "Rewiring the Pentagon: Charting a New Path on Innovation and Cybersecurity."
The office, with 15 staffers, is set to open in Moffett Field in a month.

Carter will be the first sitting Pentagon chief in nearly two decades to visit Silicon Valley. He had spent a year as a lecturer at the Freeman Spogli Institute for International Studies and as a distinguished visiting fellow at Stanford's Hoover Institution.
But Silicon Valley and the Pentagon have been at odds for years. Tech companies are especially leery of the slow-moving government agency after Edward Snowden's leaks over digital surveillance.

While in California, Carter will also meet privately with executives from Facebook (FB) at its campus in Menlo Park and the venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz, which specializes in tech companies and invested in Facebook, Groupon (GRPN), Twitter (TWTR) and Zynga (ZNGA) when they were still private.
Facebook shares rose 0.6% to 86.03 on the stock market today. Twitter shares were flat. Groupon shares rose 0.7% to 7.12. Zynga shares were up 1% to 2.54.

The Department of Homeland Security is also planning to open an office in Silicon Valley. The government has been slow to move there even as public companies from automakers to banks are heading to the region to take advantage of innovative tech ideas.
Carter is also expected to announce plans to provide venture capital funds through In-Q-Tel, a venture-capital firm set up by intelligence agencies in 1999.

Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP) vaulted to a new 14-year high Monday after reporting better-than-expected earnings and revenue. Before the open, the company said it earned 95 cents a share in Q1, compared to 84 cents a year ago and analysts' estimates of 91 cents. Revenue came in at $372.6 million — a 9% increase from a year ago and…
Check Point Software (CHKP) early Monday reported Q1 earnings that topped Wall Street views, sending the stock to a 14-year high, though its Q2 revenue outlook was slightly below analyst estimates.
The Tel Aviv, Israel-based network security vendor posted earnings per share excluding items of 95 cents, up 14% from year-earlier quarter. Revenue rose 9% to $372 million.
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected 91 cents and $370 million.
Check Point stock was up 5% in afternoon trading in the stock market today, near 86, its highest point since February 2001.
For the current quarter, Check Point forecast EPS ex items of 90 to 99 cents, up 1% to 11%, and revenue of $380 million to 400 million, up 5% to 10.5%. Analysts forecast 94 cents and $392 million.
Check Point also announced a collaboration with FireEye (FEYE) to share threat intelligence to protect customers from advanced attacks.
Of the partnership, Check Point CEO Gil Shwed told analysts on a conference call that "we want to allow the customers to exchange information between both systems."

He added: "We've talked about the need for more intelligence to fight threats. Last year we opened IntelliStore, our platform that allows organizations to receive intelligence on specific and focused security attacks relevant to them. That's what's behind our efforts with FireEye."

FireEye CEO David DeWalt said in a joint press release that "this partnership is a model for vendor cooperation that will help enterprises defend themselves against the most sophisticated cyberattacks."

Check Point last quarter rolled out Threat Extraction, a technology designed to pre-emptively remove threats from documents and reconstruct them as safe files before they're delivered to users, Shwed said.

Also last quarter, Check Point announced agreements to acquire Lacoon Mobile Security, which specializes in securing mobile devices, and Hyperwise, which has developed a central processing unit-level threat prevention engine that stops threats "at the point of pre-infection."
Check Point maintained its 2015 guidance. It calls for $1.6 billion to $1.65 billion in revenue and $3.90 to $4.02 per share ex items. Analysts have modeled $1.62 billion and $3.98.

Check Point's earnings come as the RSA Conference on cybersecurity gets underway, one of the biggest annual events for the industry. Companies are beefing up cyberdefenses in the wake of high-profile attacks against Sony (SNE), Home Depot (HD) and Target (TGT).
IBD's Computer Software-Security group ranks No. 8 of 197 groups tracked, and it's ranked no lower than No. 12 in the past six months.
Raytheon Bulks Up

Sunnyvale, Calif.-based security vendor Fortinet (FTNT) is set to report earnings after the market close Monday. Analysts expect EPS minus items of 6 cents, down 45%, on revenue of $205 million, up 21.5%.
In a separate announcement Monday, defense contractor Raytheon (RTN) said it acquired control of security vendor Websense from private-equity firm Vista Partners in a $1.9 billion deal.

FBR Capital Markets analyst Daniel Ives said in a research note Monday that the Raytheon acquisition "highlights the massive investments being allocated toward this high-priority area of IT spending as enterprises of all shapes and sizes look to bulk up legacy security systems with next-generation technologies."

Quarterly reports from Check Point Software and Fortinet on Monday pointed to a strong earnings season for computer security companies, while an acquisition by Raytheon signaled more potential deal making ahead. Cybersecurity companies are seeing double-digit growth rates at a time when overall IT spending is expected to grow just 3% to 4%, said FBR Capital Markets analyst Daniel Ives.
That was seen in Monday's results, which kick off a string of reports for the hot industry group.
Barracuda (CUDA) reports April 27, Vasco Data Security (VDSI) April 28, FireEye April 30, Qualys (QLYS) May 4, and CyberArk (CYBR) May 7.
Sunnyvale, Calif.-based Fortinet (FTNT) said Q1 billings of $254 million, up 36% year-over-year, were the highest since it became a public company more than five years ago.
While earnings fell 27% to 8 cents a share, they beat analyst forecasts by 2 cents, and revenue jumped 26% to $212 million, topping forecasts of $205 million.
Fortinet sees Q2 revenue of $224 million to $228 million, above recent forecasts, and EPS ex items of 8-9 cents, below views. Shares rallied 8% late, after closing up 2.7%.
Check Point's (CHKP) Q1 earnings climbed 14% to 95 cents a share, exceeding Wall Street views by 4 cents. Revenue rose 9% to $372 million, edging above the consensus estimate of $370 million.
Key Areas Of Focus

The Tel Aviv, Israel-based network security vendor sees EPS ex items of 90-99 cents on revenue of $380 million to $400 million. Analysts forecast earnings of 94 cents a share on revenue of $392 million.
Check Point shares finished up 5%, hitting a 14-year high.
"On the technology front, we are putting strong focus on two key areas: mobility and threat prevention," Chairman and CEO Gil Shwed said in a conference call with analysts.

He cited acquisitions of Lacoon Mobile Security, which specializes in securing mobile devices, and Hyperwise, which has developed a central processing unit-level threat prevention engine that stops threats, as strategies to boost product and service capabilities.
Check Point also announced a collaboration with FireEye (FEYE) to share threat intelligence in a move aimed at protecting customers from increasingly sophisticated attacks.
Meanwhile, top names in the industry gathered at the high-profile RSA Conference in San Francisco.

Defense contracting giant Raytheon (RTN) was among the first to make a splash at the event with an announcement that it will spend about $1.7 billion to acquire control of cybersecurity firm Websense to leverage skills it has honed for the U.S. military and intelligence agencies.
Defense-Sector Push?

The Raytheon deal speaks to the growing importance of cybersecurity to protect enterprises and government assets from malicious activity and "state attacks" from hackers in China, North Korea, Russia and Iran, Ives said.
He sees more on the horizon.

"We see traditional defense players becoming incrementally more aggressive (e.g., M&A) in the cyber security landscape as protecting sensitive data/IP remains crucial to the success of many government programs," Ives wrote in a note Monday.
Monday's Raytheon deal comes after Boeing (BA) earlier this year exited the commercial cybersecurity business.

Massive breaches and the announcement of President Obama's new cybersecurity initiatives are among issues that have thrust the information security industry into the spotlight, said Linda Gray, general manager of RSA Conference.

Some 82% of organizations expect to be attacked this year, according to the January study "State of Cybersecurity: Implications for 2015," compiled by ISACA and RSA, yet they are relying on a talent pool they view as largely unqualified and unable to handle complex threats or understand their business.

Just days after getting socked with a half-billion-dollar patent infringement penalty by a federal jury, Apple (AAPL) is facing fresh patent lawsuits.

On Tuesday, a jury in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Texas ruled that Apple's iTunes software infringed three patents held by patent licensing firm Smartflash. The federal jury ordered Apple to pay $532.9 million in damages.

On Wednesday, Smartflash decided to take another bite of the apple, suing the Cupertino, Calif.-based company for using the same patents without permission in devices introduced since the original case was filed in May 2013, Reuters reported. Those devices include the iPhone 6 series smartphones and iPad Air 2 tablet.
Proponents of patent reform called Smartflash a patent troll for using patents to shake down other companies for money instead of producing products.

"This case is Exhibit A for patent reform," Gary Shapiro, CEO of the Consumer Electronics Association, said in a statement. "The patent troll in this case doesn't produce any products and services, has zero employees and operates from an office across the street from the courthouse in the notoriously troll-friendly Eastern District of Texas.

"This sort of blatant patent extortion is exactly the reason why Congress needs to act now on patent reform. This is yet another of example of the tsunami of bogus patent claims that drain $1.5 billion a week from the U.S. economy. The only atypical aspect of this case is the defendant — the majority of patent troll victims are small firms without big legal budgets, who can easily be coerced into a settlement."
On Friday, Swedish mobile telecom-gear maker Ericsson (ERIC) said it sued Apple for patent infringement involving Ericsson's wireless communications patents and other inventions.

Ericsson on Thursday filed two complaints with the International Trade Commission and seven complaints in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Texas against Apple asserting 41 patents covering many aspects of Apple's iPhones and iPads. The patents include standard essential patents related to the 2G and 4G/LTE standards as well as patents critical to the features and functionality of Apple devices, such as chip design, user interface software, location services and applications, and the iOS operating system.
Ericsson is seeking exclusion orders in the ITC proceedings and damages and injunctions in the federal court actions.

"Apple's products benefit from the technology invented and patented by Ericsson's engineers," Kasim Alfalahi, chief intellectual property officer at Ericsson, said in a statement. "Features that consumers now take for granted — like being able to livestream television shows or access their favorite apps from their phone — rely on the technology we have developed. We are committed to sharing our innovations and have acted in good faith to find a fair solution. Apple currently uses our technology without a license and therefore we are seeking help from the court and the ITC."

Israel's economy is…

In its "Global Application & Network Security Report" for 2014-15, Radware called 2014 "a watershed year" for the cybersecurity industry, one in which cyberattacks "reached a tipping point" in terms of their quantity, length, complexity and targets.Radware (RDWR) should know. It provides integrated application delivery and network security hardware for enterprises ranging from banks and insurers to manufacturers, retailers, telecoms, government agencies, media firms and service providers.The company's core product provides load balancing, traffic management, application performance monitoring and network security. Its website boasts that it offers "complete security of business critical applications" for around 10,000 enterprises and carriers worldwide. Its partners include Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP) and Juniper Networks (JNPR).In addition to helping businesses improve productivity and profitability, and lower IT operating and infrastructure costs, Radware's cybersecurity and application delivery solutions are designed to help customers secure and manage network traffic.Safety Is SellingThe security end of the business has become "a very hot market" for Radware, says Chief Financial Officer Meir Moshe."President Obama even talked about how this is a nationwide challenge following the attack on Sony, which he said came in from North Korea," Moshe told IBD in a phone interview from his Tel Aviv office. "Companies need to be protected against cybersecurity attacks, and so we've seen an acceleration of growth in this market."Radware's technology is designed to recognize potential threats in a network's traffic and block them before they have a chance to do any damage, Moshe says. That requires sophisticated gear that can analyze anomalies in traffic so that "only legitimate traffic" flows into the network.One such product, a new version of Radware's DefensePro platform, was launched this month. It is designed to help high-end cloud service providers mitigate sophisticated attacks by providing more security capacity."Security in the cloud is our main focus for 2015," Moshe said. "We have put a lot of resources into this because it is a very high-demand and growing market."Analysts likewise have a bullish outlook on the cybersecurity market, as well as Radware's growth opportunities in it.New ServicesIn a research note, Imperial Capital analyst Michael Kim said he anticipates "continued strong growth driven by increasing demand" for Radware's security solutions."We see particular opportunities for broadening deployments of application security and data center protection solutions, with potential upside from new cloud security services — e.g., managed attack mitigation and web application firewall," Kim noted.Buckingham Research analyst Rohit Chopra calls Radware "one of the most compelling hybrid ways to play strong secular trends in security."He expects Radware to increase R&D; and other spending as a way to capture new cybersecurity opportunities as well as prepare for a new partnership with a still-unnamed original equipment manufacturer (OEM) that Chopra says will likely be a "large networking provider."Partnership PlanningMoshe would not divulge the name of the OEM, though he did confirm that the OEM will be identified during the second quarter and that revenue from the relationship will start coming in during the second half of the year.Financially, Radware continues to bounce back from a sluggish 2013, when it reported lower earnings and only a slight increase in sales. Part of the problem then was fierce competition that drove down prices, Moshe says.Thanks to a bigger emphasis on higher-margin security products, Radware has now posted four straight quarters of double-digit sales and earnings growth, the first time that's happened since 2012.On Jan. 28, Radware reported fourth-quarter earnings of 28 cents a share, up from 22 cents a year earlier and a penny above the consensus view of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue climbed 15% to $61 million, also slightly above estimates.The company's operating margins expanded to 22% at the end of 2014 from 14% at the end of the year.Radware's stock price sank 12% to 19.72 after it guided Q1 sales and earnings at the low end of analyst expectations. Shares have since regained some ground and currently trade near 22.For the full year, Radware's EPS grew 25% to 86 cents while revenue climbed 15% to $222 million — the biggest annual top-line gain since 2011.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Radware to increase 2015 earnings by 20% to $1.03 a share and revenue by 12% to $247.9 million."By focusing on high-performance capabilities, tight integration of multiple services and multiple deployment options, Radware is carving out a defensible portion of the application delivery assurance market," D.A. Davidson analyst Mark Kelleher noted in a research report.He reckons Radware's "continued innovation" will let the company "expand its addressable market and maintain mid-teens top-line growth for at least the next three years."Radware has an IBD Composite Rating of 95, factoring in metrics such as earnings growth and stock-price gains. It belongs to IBD's Computer-Networking industry group, which ranks No. 45 in performance among 197 tracked.Radware is the top-rated stock in the group. Other high-rated stocks in the group include QLogic (QLGC), Arista Networks (ANET) and Ruckus Wireless (RKUS).

Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP) announced Wednesday that it acquired Tel Aviv, Israel-based startup Hyperwise, which has developed new central processing unit-level threat-prevention technology.

Internet and network security provider Check Point, also based in Tel Aviv, said in a press release that current approaches to threat prevention have traditionally focused on detecting and blocking malware after the malware is already active. The result is an "unaddressed threat gap" in the earlier phases of attack.
With Hyperwise's CPU-level threat prevention technology, Check Point says it will be able to address the gap by enabling the detection of threats at the pre-infection stage.
Terms weren't disclosed.
Hyperwise was founded in 2013 by Shlomo Kramer, a co-founder of Check Point, who left that company more than a decade ago.
Check Point stock was up a fraction in midday trading in the stock market today, near 81.

Check Point stock is within pennies of a 14-year high of 81.57 touched on Jan. 20. IBD's 23-company Computer Software-Security group, which ranks No. 4 of 197 groups, is up more than 40% the past four months amid high-profile security breaches and extra attention on security by President Obama and government officials.
Recent top performers in the group include Palo Alto Networks (PANW) and CyberArk Software (CYBR), which was up 6% midday Wednesday, continuing a strong runup since its earnings beat last week.

Check Point CEO Gil Shwed said on a Q4 conference call with analysts Jan. 29 that the company will invest this year to develop new solutions for threat prevention and mobility, as well as hire additional researchers for security software development.

Check Point expects Q1 revenue of $360 million to $375 million, up 5% to 10% year-over-year, and EPS minus items of 89 cents to 93 cents, up 6% to 11%. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters have modeled on $370 million and EPS ex items of 91 cents.
On Jan. 29, Check Point reported Q4 earnings and revenue that beat expectations.

Check Point last year introduced its Check Point Capsule security software, which is designed to protect business data and mobile devices by attaching security that travels with documents to prevent internal and external data leaks.

"It provides a secure workforce on mobile devices and, most importantly, is designed to provide end-to-end data security," Shwed said on the conference call. "All documents are encrypted when they are created, classified according to the relevant group and shared on all mobile and non-mobile devices securely."

Check Point also established an IntelliStore, which allows organizations to receive intelligence on specific and focused security attacks that are relevant to them.Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP) announced Wednesday that it acquired Tel Aviv, Israel-based startup Hyperwise, which has developed new central processing unit-level threat-prevention technology.Internet and network security provider Check Point, also based in Tel Aviv, said in a press release that current approaches to threat prevention have traditionally focused on detecting and blocking malware after the malware is already active. The result is an "unaddressed threat gap" in the earlier phases of attack.With Hyperwise's CPU-level threat prevention technology, Check Point says it will be able to address the gap by enabling the detection of threats at the pre-infection stage.Terms weren't disclosed.Hyperwise was founded in 2013 by Shlomo Kramer, a co-founder of Check Point, who left that company more than a decade ago.Check Point stock was up a fraction in midday trading in the stock market today, near 81.Check Point stock is within pennies of a 14-year high of 81.57 touched on Jan. 20. TEL AVIV, Israel — The public rift between President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu over the Iranian nuclear issue is often described as a personality dispute. But a senior Israeli official argued that the break has been building for more than two years and reflects a deep disagreement about how best to limit the threat of a rising Iran.…

Mideast: Tehran told U.S. diplomats to tell Israel to "await the consequences" for killing one of its generals. The radical state the president thinks will abandon nuclear weapons development treats the U.S. as its courier service.We learned this week from Megyn Kelly's Fox News interview with State Department spokeswoman Jen Psaki that Secretary of State John Kerry is a "hugger."Kerry had just gone to Paris the week after missing the anti-terrorism march he should have gone to, and told the French: "I really wanted to come here and share a hug with all of Paris."We can probably expect hugging if the U.S. and its partners finally get a nuclear deal with Iran, but the Iranians this week once again reminded us that evil can't be caressed into good.Tehran's Deputy Foreign Minister Hossein Amir Abdollahian confided to the official Iranian news agency on Tuesday that, using diplomatic channels, "we told the Americans that the leaders of the Zionist regime should await the consequences of their act" of killing an Iranian general.Abdollahian added sarcastically, in a reference to President Obama's called bluff on chemical weapons in Syria, "the Zionist regime has crossed our red lines."A Jan. 18 airstrike in the Golan Heights, almost certainly conducted by Israeli jets, killed Gen. Mohammad Ali Allahdadi, along with a half-dozen Iranian-backed Hezbollah terrorists.The "consequences" threatened against the Jewish state for the bombing are likely not to resemble a hug; if Iran today had nuclear weapons, Tel Aviv might find itself within the embrace of a mushroom cloud.Hugging our adversaries into submission seems to be a favorite State Department diplomatic tool these days. As the Washington Free Beacon reports, high-ranking Muslim Brotherhood-aligned opponents of Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi of Egypt this week came to Foggy Bottom and had what one called "fruitful" talks with the Obama administration.This is the same Muslim Brotherhood whose strategic goal, according to a 1991 memorandum by one of its operatives, is "eliminating and destroying the Western civilization from within and sabotaging its miserable house by their hands and the hands of the believers so that it is eliminated and God's religion is made victorious over all other religions."One member of the Muslim Brotherhood delegation posted a smiling photo of himself online within the corridors of the State Department, holding up four fingers to make the pro-terrorist Rabia sign before the U.S. Great Seal. The Egyptian government considers the sign a terrorist symbol and inflicts legal punishment on those who use it.So the Obama administration entertains Egyptian jihadists because it thinks — hopes? — they might get back into power. But the president won't meet with our ally in Israel, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, when he visits Washington to address Congress in a few weeks. It claims a meeting would inappropriately affect Israel's upcoming election.When a major world power doesn't know what it stands for or whom it stands with, it stops being taken seriously. No wonder the Iranians now mistake America for the hired help and hand us messages to deliver.

The conflict between Israel and Palestinians caused the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration on Tuesday to temporarily ban American flights to and from Tel Aviv's Ben Gurion International Airport after a rocket landed near the facility.
The airport is about the same distance from the tiny territory known as the Gaza Strip as the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange (TASE).
Israel launched ground operations against Gaza July 17, responding to missiles fired into Israel from that area.
Authorities reported 611 Palestinians and 29 Israelis had died in the fighting.
But Israel's markets have shown little reaction.

Since hostilities began, the shekel has strengthened vs. the dollar. Indexes traded broadly higher on the Tel Aviv exchange Tuesday and have showed little shakiness since the start of Israel's offensive vs. Gaza.
Israel ETFs Stay Strong
In the U.S., Israel-focused ETFs, iShares MSCI Israel (EIS) and Market Vector Israel (ISRA) have reacted by rising 1% and 2%, respectively, the past two weeks. For the year, they are up 9% and 4.5%.
Among leading Israel-based, U.S.-traded stocks, Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP) is trying to rebound above the key 10-week moving average.
Teva Pharmaceuticals (TEVA), the largest name on Israel's TA-25 index, nosed up to a four-year high Tuesday.
Chipmaker Mellanox Technologies (MLNX) climbed 2% Tuesday. The stock jumped more than 8% last week after an upgrade from Jefferies.
Other Israel-based stocks shrugging off the war include Tower Semiconductor (TSEM) and various thinly traded plays, including Taro Pharmaceutical (TARO) and Caesarstone (CSTE).
Maybe of greater concern to Israeli investors is the possible loss of Perrigo (PRGO) from the Tel Aviv's exchange.
The Michigan-based, Dublin-domiciled drugmaker, dual-listed on the TASE since it bought Agis in 2005, announced last week it was exploring options for a possible sale.
Recent acquisitions, including Given Imaging and Retalix, de-listed from the TASE following the deals.

Qualcomm could gain from Chinese smartphone maker Xiaomi Technology's legal battle in India amid expectations that China's government will soon issue a ruling on its antitrust probe of Qualcomm.

An Indian court on Tuesday temporarily allowed Xiaomi to sell some mobile phones in the country, a week after it asked the Chinese company to suspend sales after Sweden-based Ericsson (ERIC) filed a patent infringement lawsuit against Xiaomi. A hearing is slated for Jan. 8.

"We believe the activity in India is timely for Qualcomm's ongoing investigation in China, as it demonstrates to Chinese firms the hazards of exporting without adequate intellectual property rights," Tim Long, a BMO Capital analyst, said in a research report. "We believe other Chinese vendors could face similar bans in other countries, should Qualcomm determine that the Chinese government's ruling is too unfavorable."

China's National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) is conducting an anti-monopoly review involving Qualcomm. The outcome could affect Qualcomm's ability to collect royalties from Chinese mobile phone makers.

The stakes are big, because Chinese smartphone makers have been gaining market share in their home market as well as globally, though South Korea-based Samsung and Apple (AAPL) remain the top two sellers.

President Obama last month reportedly pressed China President Xi Jinping to stop using the anti-monopoly law to limit royalties paid by Chinese companies, Reuters reported. At least 30 foreign firms, including San Diego-based Qualcomm, have come under the scrutiny of China's 2008 anti-monopoly law, the report said.
"We see the U.S. government's involvement as a positive, as an unfavorable ruling could potentially damage international relations, in addition to its impact on Qualcomm," Long said.
He speculates Qualcomm could aid Xiaomi, which is a customer, in its legal battle in India through a cross-licensing deal with Ericsson.
Qualcomm stock was up 1% in early trading in the stock market today.
RELATED:

Middle East: What is the U.S. doing turning the screws on our most loyal ally in the region, with the Federal Aviation Administration used as a wrench? Have we forgotten the real enemy?Secretary of State John Kerry flies in to Tel Aviv on Wednesday, amidst heavy fighting between Israel and Hamas terrorists, to give an earful to Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. He may have met with Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas too in his frantic "shuttle diplomacy."But we all know who the administration believes is the instigator of this latest chapter of the conflict.After all, we didn't hear the president or the State Department over the last few days ask Hamas to avoid killing civilians — though that's pretty much what Hamas does, with innocent victims being both Jews and Arabs. That scolding was saved for Israel, the country that drops leaflets warning Arab civilians to flee for safety.Netanyahu reportedly let Kerry know he resented the FAA's ban on flights into Tel Aviv, since rescinded, judging it to be a political move aimed at pressuring Israel to agree to halt hostilities.Kerry meanwhile praised Abbas "for his leadership, for his deep engagement in the effort to try to find a cease-fire." Shouldn't Netanyahu be praised for his leadership in the self-defense of his people, upon whom rockets have been raining down?In spite of our ever-shuttling secretary, expectations for peace right now are close to nil. And for a glaringly obvious reason: U.S. power, prestige and moral authority are on the wane.Barack Obama came into office promising a diplomatic prowess never encountered before in world history.Over tea with the president of Iran he would persuade a regime sworn to wage war on America and wipe out its Zionist enemy to abandon its nuclear weapons ambitions.He would divert resources from the "dumb war" in Iraq to win the crucial war in Afghanistan; he might even invade Pakistan, he warned. We ended up losing both wars.Iraq is a disaster, with an al-Qaida offshoot forming a new caliphate across parts of both Syria and Iraq. Meanwhile, the Taliban are both warring and PR-ing their way back toward a return to power in Afghanistan.The president's "New Beginning" with the Muslim Mideast hasn't persuaded Hamas, or the Taliban, or Iran's ayatollah, or the region's myriad new al-Qaida mutations to get civilized and stop waging jihad against Americans, Europeans and Israelis.The new American stance — global weakness in the face of enemies, combined with betrayal of friends and allies — has, however, made it harder for us to get Israel to follow our wishes. Earlier this year, Obama became so desperate he even floated releasing convicted Israeli spy Jonathan Pollard. Netanyahu wasn't buying.The Mideast, as complex as it is in its particulars, is in essence a contest between Western civilization and violent Islamist chaos. This administration has forgotten which side America is on.

Healthy demand and corporate contract revenue gains lifted Delta Air Lines (DAL) as Q2 earnings rose 6.1% to $1.04 a share, beating analyst estimates by a penny. Revenue rose 9.4% to $10.62 billion, just barely missing views for $10.65 billion. Operating revenue increased 9% year over year on corporate and domestic revenue.

Earnings growth slowed sharply after a rapid ascent, accelerating from 42% in Q2 2013 to 230% in Q1. Delta warned on July 7 of weak demand for higher-margin international flights. Germany's Lufthansa warned in June that increased competition from rapidly expanding Gulf airlines would hurt earnings.

Those warnings sent shares of Delta and other global carriers sharply lower in June and early July. But Delta shares rose 3.6% to 39.04 in the stock market today, moving back above their 50-day moving average.
"It was an outstanding quarter," CRT Capital analyst Michael Derchin told IBD. "(Delta was) hitting on all cylinders."
He added that Delta's Q2 adjusted operating margins of 15.1% were ahead of CRT's estimates for 14.5%, with the Q3 guidance for operating margins of 15% to 17% better than expected.
Delta had expected an operating margin of 14%-16% for the quarter ended in June.
The airline said its passenger revenue rose 9% and passenger unit revenue increased 5.7%, while cargo revenue dipped 1%.

"A solid demand environment, coupled with higher revenues from our corporate contract gains, merchandising efforts, and investments in New York and Seattle, helped offset weakness in Pacific yields and resulted in a nearly 6% increase in Delta's unit revenues for the June quarter," said Delta President Ed Bastian in a release.
United Continental (UAL), American Airlines (AAL), Southwest Airlines (LUV), Alaska Air (ALK) and JetBlue Airways (JBLU) all report Thursday. Shares of all five carriers rallied Wednesday morning.

On Tuesday, Delta and others temporarily suspended service to Israel following an FAA warning about a rocket attack near Ben Gurion International Airport. A Delta Boeing (BA) flight to Tel Aviv had to divert to Paris earlier that day.
Follow Elaine Low on Twitter at @IBD_ELow.
RELATED:

Iran: Secretary of State John Kerry is working oh-so-hard in Vienna for a nuclear weapons deal with Tehran. Whether our nation's top diplomat gets one or not, the talks have been a dangerous waste of time.In what the New York Times on Tuesday called "an indication of the complexity of the talks and Mr. Kerry's negotiating style" the Newspaper of Record reported that "immediately after his news conference he launched into a meeting with Catherine Ashton, the foreign policy chief for the European Union, and then yet another meeting with Mohammad Javad Zarif, Iran's foreign minister, his fourth in three days."What a shame it would be, we apparently are supposed to think, if these arduous negotiations with Iran — which looked like a slam dunk to so many last November — were to fail.In fact, all these months the U.S. and Europe have spent talking to Iran have taken our eyes off the ball on what Iran is really up to: becoming the greatest nuclear threat to the world since the Soviet Union.The negotiations' success would probably be worse than their failure.As former U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations John Bolton told Fox News on Tuesday, President Obama is under the delusional impression that the fanatical Islamofascist regime can be both nuclear and unthreatening, that we can "leave them with only a peaceful nuclear power and research program."Tehran's position is that under any agreement it be allowed to develop sophisticated centrifuges; Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei insists Iran might "need" tens of thousands of centrifuges.This from the country with, at 150 billion barrels, the third largest amount of proven oil reserves in the world, and no need for nuclear power at all.Kerry contended that there is "no question" Iran is entitled to a nuclear program: "What we are trying to do is find a way for Iran to have an exclusively peaceful nuclear program while giving the world all the assurances required to know that Iran is not seeking a nuclear weapon."And he claimed, "I want to underscore: These goals are not incompatible. In fact, they are realistic. But we have not yet found the right combination or arrived at the workable formula."Substitute Nazi Germany for Iran and it becomes clear how absurd such a notion is.What happens if the July 20 deadline passes is that a new deadline gets activated, possibly six months or maybe a shorter time.Which means more time for Iranian nuclear weaponization while perfecting the missiles upon which an atomic bomb could destroy Tel Aviv or, some day, a European city."These are tough negotiations," Kerry tells us, and "very real gaps remain," and presumably we're all supposed to root for him to come home with a glorious signed piece of paper.Empathy may be one of Obama's criteria for Supreme Court nominees, but feeling for the secretary of state in a Vienna negotiating room is a fool's errand.How many times has the loser of the 2004 presidential campaign lost in the diplomatic sphere since he replaced Hillary Clinton at Foggy Bottom last year?Let us count the ways.He couldn't get an Israeli-Palestinian agreement.He couldn't get an agreement with Afghanistan on legal immunity for U.S. forces.And an idiotic slip of the tongue on Syria's chemical weapons led to Russian ruler Vladimir Putin gladly stepping in to fill the growing vacuum of U.S. power and prestige in the Mideast.Barring Israel bombing Tehran's nuclear facilities to smithereens, which may end up as the only real solution, Kerry will also lose on Iran, no matter how these talks pan out.Because with or without a pact, a nuclear-armed ayatollah will remain a continued threat to the U.S. and the rest of the West.
Palo Alto Networks, a leading stock pick, has vaulted higher as it puts a patent dispute to bed and as analysts see its security products in demand at data centers.
Known for network firewalls and other corporate security offerings, Palo Alto Networks (PANW) makes the IBD Leaderboard list of high-potential stocks. On Monday, it pushed up more than 3% to 83.85.

"PANW remains a top pick for 2014, our favorite play on the secular trend toward consolidated network-security functionality," Morgan Stanley analyst Keith Weiss wrote in an early-Monday research note boosting his price target to 105.

Weiss says several factors, including corporate security purchasing plans, bolster his confidence that the company can sustain 30% or better billings growth in fiscal 2015. He also notes that the company will see slower growth in capital expenditures and a reduction in litigation expenses.

Palo Alto Networks offers a next-generation network-security platform used by enterprises, service providers and government entities to protect their networks from viruses, malware and other threats. Its lineup includes network firewall software and hardware. It also sells subscription services for threat detection and prevention, web filtering and mobile device security.
Patent Issue Past

Palo Alto Networks stock is up 46% this year and 21% since the firm announced the end of a legal saga May 28 and released third-quarter fiscal 2014 results. They topped estimates with 49% year-over-year revenue growth to $150.7 million, and 57% earnings growth to 11 cents a share.

"These results were driven by continued strong product demand, robust service growth and a rapid market-share gain in the large and growing strategic enterprise security market," CEO Mark McLaughlin said on a call with analysts at the time, noting the firm had "settled all existing litigation with Juniper."

Palo Alto Networks paid $175 million to settle a suit in which Juniper Networks (JNPR) claimed that Palo Alto Networks products infringed on six of its patents. Under terms of the deal, Palo Alto Networks agreed to make a one-time payment of $75 million in cash and pay $100 million in shares of common stock and warrants to buy common stock.

Juniper Networks filed the suit in December 2011. Palo Alto Networks later accused the company of infringing on three of its patents. As part of the settlement, the two firms agreed to license the patents at issue to each other and not file infringement suits for the next eight years.

"As we said from the beginning of this case, we do not believe that we infringed on any Juniper patents, and we still believe this to be the case," McLaughlin said on the Q3 call. "However, over the course of the last 2-1/2 years, we've spent a large amount of time, money and other resources on this litigation. ... We believe that this outcome will allow us to continue to focus our efforts in what we do best: innovating and developing new products, servicing our customers and the growth that results from that."

Although $175 million is a hefty sum for a company with less than $400 million in revenue as recently as its last fiscal year, the settlement did remove "a key overhang" on Palo Alto Networks stock, says FBN Securities analyst Shebly Seyrafi.
Stock Sets New High
With the overhang gone, Palo Alto Networks stock, which debuted in an IPO two years ago, hit a record high of 82.27 on June 17 and then passed that by almost 2% Monday.
The settlement is also seen resolving hesitancy on the part of some customers to do business with Palo Alto Networks as long as the lawsuit was up in the air.
"With this removal, we think Palo Alto can experience incrementally more sales," Seyrafi noted.

Palo Alto Networks seeks to continue expanding an operation that already includes 16,000-plus customers in more than 120 countries across multiple industries. One potential growth area is in the enterprise market, where it looks to win business with a next-generation security firewall designed for corporate data centers.
Guard For Data Centers

Palo Alto Networks' new PA-7050 security appliance will help it gain market share in the enterprise market, analysts predict. The product, launched in February, provides up to 120 gigabits per second of throughput speed to analyze threats to corporate data centers.

"Palo Alto has plenty of room left to take share in enterprise network security," Pacific Crest Securities analyst Rob Owens wrote in a report. "Data-center deployments account for over 30% of Palo Alto's product revenue, and the release of the PA-7050 appliance expands the opportunity into even higher-performance environments."

Meanwhile, analysts praise Palo Alto Networks' ability to win new business in a competitive field that includes pure plays such as Juniper, Symantec (SYMC) and Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP), plus broader hardware and software firms such as Cisco Systems (CSCO).

"Palo Alto is the clear market leader and is defining the market in the next-generation firewall space," Citi Investment Research analyst Walter Pritchard noted. "With clear differentiation and technology leadership, we see continued share gains ahead for Palo Alto."

Among factors working for Palo Alto Networks' potential, Morgan Stanley analyst Weiss notes that 43% of corporate security executives polled plan a firewall refresh (upgrades and replacements) this year vs. 23% last year. And with only 10% using Palo Alto for their primary firewall and/or unified threat-management needs now, he sees room for market share gains.
Weiss says the company has strong positioning and an improving margin trend past fiscal 2015.
More Acquisitions Ahead?

As Palo Alto Networks gains size, it may also eye more buyouts as a way to expand its piece of the pie, analysts say. The firm has not made a huge number of deals through the years, though it has made a couple in 2014. In January, it acquired Morta Security, a Silicon Valley-based cybersecurity company, for an undisclosed sum. In April, it completed its $200 million buyout of Cyvera, a privately held cybersecurity company in Tel Aviv, Israel.

Palo Alto Networks might be set for more acquisitions after its recent decision to issue $500 million of convertible senior notes due in 2019. In a research note, William Blair analyst Jonathan Ho said Palo Alto intends to use the proceeds for general corporate purposes, which include working capital, capital expenditures, potential acquisitions and strategic transactions.

"We believe the funds from the convertible offering would provide the company with significant latitude to further broaden its technology and next-generation security-solution suite, as it did with its recent acquisition of Cyvera to enter the endpoint-protection space in what we view to be a very positive fashion," Ho said.
A Palo Alto Networks spokeswoman said no company officials were available to speak for this story.

Financially, Palo Alto Networks continues showing robust growth, notching year-over-year revenue gains of at least 46% each quarter since going public. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect EPS of 40 cents for fiscal 2014, which ends in July, up from 21 cents last year. It also sells subscription services for threat detection and prevention, web filtering and mobile device security.Patent Issue PastPalo Alto Networks stock is up 46% this year and 21% since the firm announced the end of a legal saga May 28 and released third-quarter fiscal 2014 results. They topped estimates with 49% year-over-year revenue growth to $150.7 million, and 57% earnings growth to 11 cents a share."These results were driven by continued strong product demand, robust service growth and a rapid market-share gain in the large and growing strategic enterprise security market," CEO Mark McLaughlin said on a call with analysts at the time, noting the firm had "settled all existing litigation with Juniper."Palo Alto Networks paid $175 million to settle a suit in which Juniper Networks (JNPR) claimed that Palo Alto Networks products infringed on six of its patents. Under terms of the deal, Palo Alto Networks agreed to make a one-time payment of $75 million in cash and pay $100 million in shares of common stock and warrants to buy common stock.Juniper Networks filed the suit in December 2011. Palo Alto Networks later accused the company of infringing on three of its patents. As part of the settlement, the two firms agreed to license the patents at issue to each other and not file infringement suits for the next eight years."As we said from the beginning of this case, we do not believe that we infringed on any Juniper patents, and we still believe this to be the case," McLaughlin said on the Q3 call. "However, over the course of the last 2-1/2 years, we've spent a large amount of time, money and other resources on this litigation. ... We believe that this outcome will allow us to continue to focus our efforts in what we do best: innovating and developing new products, servicing our customers and the growth that results from that."Although $175 million is a hefty sum for a company with less than $400 million in revenue as recently as its last fiscal year, the settlement did remove "a key overhang" on Palo Alto Networks stock, says FBN Securities analyst Shebly Seyrafi.Stock Sets New HighWith the overhang gone, Palo Alto Networks stock, which debuted in an IPO two years ago, hit a record high of 82.27 on June 17 and then passed that by almost 2% Monday.The settlement is also seen resolving hesitancy on the part of some customers to do business with Palo Alto Networks as long as the lawsuit was up in the air."With this removal, we think Palo Alto can experience incrementally more sales," Seyrafi noted.Palo Alto Networks seeks to continue expanding an operation that already includes 16,000-plus customers in more than 120 countries across multiple industries. One potential growth area is in the enterprise market, where it looks to win business with a next-generation security firewall designed for corporate data centers.Guard For Data CentersPalo Alto Networks' new PA-7050 security appliance will help it gain market share in the enterprise market, analysts predict. The product, launched in February, provides up to 120 gigabits per second of throughput speed to analyze threats to corporate data centers."Palo Alto has plenty of room left to take share in enterprise network security," Pacific Crest Securities analyst Rob Owens wrote in a report. "Data-center deployments account for over 30% of Palo Alto's product revenue, and the release of the PA-7050 appliance expands the opportunity into even higher-performance environments."Meanwhile, analysts praise Palo Alto Networks' ability to win new business in a competitive field that includes pure plays such as Juniper, Symantec (SYMC) and Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP), plus broader hardware and software firms such as Cisco Systems (CSCO)."Palo Alto is the clear market leader and is defining the market in the next-generation firewall space," Citi Investment Research analyst Walter Pritchard noted. "With clear differentiation and technology leadership, we see continued share gains ahead for Palo Alto."Among factors working for Palo Alto Networks' potential, Morgan Stanley analyst Weiss notes that 43% of corporate security executives polled plan a firewall refresh (upgrades and replacements) this year vs. 23% last year. And with only 10% using Palo Alto for their primary firewall and/or unified threat-management needs now, he sees room for market share gains.Weiss says the company has strong positioning and an improving margin trend past fiscal 2015.More Acquisitions Ahead?As Palo Alto Networks gains size, it may also eye more buyouts as a way to expand its piece of the pie, analysts say. The firm has not made a huge number of deals through the years, though it has made a couple in 2014. In January, it acquired Morta Security, a Silicon Valley-based cybersecurity company, for an undisclosed sum. In April, it completed its $200 million buyout of Cyvera, a privately held cybersecurity company in Tel Aviv, Israel.Palo Alto Networks might be set for more acquisitions after its recent decision to issue $500 million of convertible senior notes due in 2019. In a research note, William Blair analyst Jonathan Ho said Palo Alto intends to use the proceeds for general corporate purposes, which include working capital, capital expenditures, potential acquisitions and strategic transactions."We believe the funds from the convertible offering would provide the company with significant latitude to further broaden its technology and next-generation security-solution suite, as it did with its recent acquisition of Cyvera to enter the endpoint-protection space in what we view to be a very positive fashion," Ho said.A Palo Alto Networks spokeswoman said no company officials were available to speak for this story.Financially, Palo Alto Networks continues showing robust growth, notching year-over-year revenue gains of at least 46% each quarter since going public. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect EPS of 40 cents for fiscal 2014, which ends in July, up from 21 cents last year. Fiscal 2015 earnings are seen rising 65% to 66 cents a share.

Many of you were no doubt busy at work these past 24 hours or seeking work or giving up seeking work. So we've thoughtfully assembled a quick update of the more important news during this period:Russian President Vladimir Putin sent his reply to President Obama's demand to rein in Russian insurgents scorching eastern Ukraine. Using Putin's Buk missiles, the rebels downed two more Ukrainian fighter jets; one pilot was killed, the other ejected over insurgents and his fate can only be guessed.Crash investigators arrived in the same area to poke through what's left of the Malaysian passenger jet wreckage downed by a previous Russian Buk. Their work was hampered by continuous fighting.The first few dozen victim's bodies arrived back in the Netherlands, the downed flight's origin, and thousands silently lined streets as hearses passed.In Iraq, the last living Christians were ejected from Mosul, where people of their faith were living 600 years before Islam arrived. Last week, the terrorist army ISIS, consolidating control now over large regions of Iraq and Syria, said they all must leave, convert or die. Their homes and belongings were confiscated.ISIS executions of Shiites, soldiers and others continued, while international experts predicted a full assault on Baghdad to mark the end of the holy month of Ramadan next week.In Syria, international observers said the civil war had seen the bloodiest 48 hours since 2011 with more than 700 dying.In Gaza, heavy fighting continued between an Israeli incursion force bent on destroying terrorist tunnels into Israel and Hamas.United Nations officials found a second cache of deadly Hamas rockets stored in a civilian UN school. As an international organization dedicated to peace, UN authorities returned the weapons to the Hamas fighter, who weren't busy parading wounded human shields for TV cameras.More Hamas rockets were fired blindly into Israel, most of them met by anti-rocket fire. Secy. of State John Kerry took a break from talking fruitlessly to Iran's nuclear weapons negotiators to continue talking fruitlessly with Palestinian authorities about a proposed Egyptian ceasefire that Israel already accepted.The Federal Aviation Administration lifted its strange two-day ban on U.S. commercial jets flying into Tel Aviv, where usual air traffic had continued.On Capitol Hill, the Senate Veterans Affairs Committee voted 14-0 to confirm Bob McDonald, a former Army officer and Procter & Gamble CEO, as secretary of the scandal-plagued Veterans Administration.In Florida, Marine veteran Jeffrey Duck patiently waited more than three hours at a VA clinic for his prescription refill. Then, he phoned 911. The reason: Duck realized the entire clinic staff had gone home for the night and locked him inside. VA officials promised to review procedures, not on serving waiting vets faster, but on how they go about closing.Meanwhile, despite all these international and domestic distractions, Obama bravely carried on with his intense party fundraising duties. He's doing six fundraisers in three days in the Democrats' main West Coast political ATM's of Seattle, San Francisco and Los Angeles.To give you a flavor of the commander-in-chief's remarks, here are excerpts from his Wednesday evening speech to 450 supporters in the luxurious home of Shonda Rimes:"Hello, everybody. Hello, Los Angeles. Oh, this is a nice looking crowd. You all got dressed up. Don’t you look cute? Everybody, have a seat.....It is good to be in Los Angeles. Let me first of all say thank you to Shonda for opening up this unbelievable space and arranging for perfect weather. Give Shonda a big round of applause.....We love Shonda."Kerry Washington I want to thank.....She didn’t jump on the (Obama) bandwagon. She pushed when the wagon was stuck in the mud ....She’s just been a great friend. Plus she showed me her baby pictures, and that is one cute baby. And I want to thank her and the entire host committee for helping to set this up."My girl, Janelle Monae. Janelle has performed at the White House, like, 15 times.....Michelle and I love Janelle..... I have to say nice things about her because she may be the only person in possession of a video in which I try to keep up with her and Usher on the dance floor. Now, this is top secret. She has promised that this will never be released.....Now, tell the truth though, Janelle. I wasn’t bad, though, was I? I’m just saying."Obama said for some reason, "People across the country still feel anxious. And the question is, why?" He traced the anxiety to stagnant wages and the House of Representatives.He said Americans "are concerned about some of the turmoil that’s taking place around the world. And they look at the Middle East and they see a transition from an old order to a new order, and they’re not sure how that’s going to happen, and the terrible violence that occurs as a result."But Obama said never mind deadly violence, "the conflict that probably makes people most discouraged is the conflict they see in Washington, where members of Congress can’t seem to do anything; where all we hear about is gridlock, and all we hear about is posturing, and all we hear about are phony scandals."The Democrat reassured his audience, most of whom paid thousands of dollars, "I don’t think it’s an exaggeration to say that by almost every economic measure we’re better off now" than five years ago.
